segment.source: You can use the dynamic configuration to customize an App-V 5.1 package for a user.
segment.target: You can use the dynamic configuration to customize an App-V 5.1 package for a user.

segment.source: Use the following information to create or edit an existing dynamic configuration file.
segment.target: Use the following information to create or edit an existing dynamic configuration file.

segment.source: When you edit the dynamic configuration file it customizes how an App-V 5.1 package will run for a user or group.
segment.target: When you edit the dynamic configuration file it customizes how an App-V 5.1 package will run for a user or group.

segment.source: This helps to provide a more convenient method for package customization by removing the need to re-sequence packages using the desired settings, and provides a way to keep package content and custom settings independent.
segment.target: This helps to provide a more convenient method for package customization by removing the need to re-sequence packages using the desired settings, and provides a way to keep package content and custom settings independent.

segment.source: Virtual application packages contain a manifest that provides all the core information for the package.
segment.target: Virtual application packages contain a manifest that provides all the core information for the package.

segment.source: This information includes the defaults for the package settings and determines settings in the most basic form (with no additional customization).
segment.target: This information includes the defaults for the package settings and determines settings in the most basic form (with no additional customization).

segment.source: If you want to adjust these defaults for a particular user or group, you can create and edit the following files:
segment.target: If you want to adjust these defaults for a particular user or group, you can create and edit the following files:

segment.source: The previous .xml files specify package settings and allow for packages to be customized without directly affecting the packages.
segment.target: The previous .xml files specify package settings and allow for packages to be customized without directly affecting the packages.

segment.source: When a package is created, the sequencer automatically generates default deployment and user configuration .xml files using the package manifest data.
segment.target: When a package is created, the sequencer automatically generates default deployment and user configuration .xml files using the package manifest data.

segment.source: Therefore, these automatically generated configuration files simply reflect the default settings that the package innately as from how things were configured during sequencing.
segment.target: Therefore, these automatically generated configuration files simply reflect the default settings that the package innately as from how things were configured during sequencing.

segment.source: If you apply these configuration files to a package in the form generated by the sequencer, the packages will have the same default settings that came from their manifest.
segment.target: If you apply these configuration files to a package in the form generated by the sequencer, the packages will have the same default settings that came from their manifest.

segment.source: This provides you with a package-specific template to get started if any of the defaults must be changed.
segment.target: This provides you with a package-specific template to get started if any of the defaults must be changed.

segment.source: The following information can only be used to modify sequencer generated configuration files to customize packages to meet specific user or group requirements.
segment.target: The following information can only be used to modify sequencer generated configuration files to customize packages to meet specific user or group requirements.

segment.source: All of the additions, deletions, and updates in the configuration files need to be made in relation to the default values specified by the package's manifest information.
segment.target: All of the additions, deletions, and updates in the configuration files need to be made in relation to the default values specified by the package's manifest information.

segment.source: The previous table represents how the files will be read.
segment.target: The previous table represents how the files will be read.

segment.source: The first entry represents what will be read last, therefore, its content takes precedence.
segment.target: The first entry represents what will be read last, therefore, its content takes precedence.

segment.source: Therefore, all packages inherently contain and provide default settings from the package manifest.
segment.target: Therefore, all packages inherently contain and provide default settings from the package manifest.

segment.source: If a deployment configuration .xml file with customized settings is applied, it will override the package manifest defaults.
segment.target: If a deployment configuration .xml file with customized settings is applied, it will override the package manifest defaults.

segment.source: If a user configuration .xml file with customized settings is applied prior to that, it will override both the deployment configuration and the package manifest defaults.
segment.target: If a user configuration .xml file with customized settings is applied prior to that, it will override both the deployment configuration and the package manifest defaults.

segment.source: The following list displays more information about the two file types:
segment.target: The following list displays more information about the two file types:

segment.source: User Configuration File (UserConfig) – Allows you to specify or modify custom settings for a package.
segment.target: User Configuration File (UserConfig) – Allows you to specify or modify custom settings for a package.

segment.source: These settings will be applied for a specific user when the package is deployed to a computer running the App-V 5.1 client.
segment.target: These settings will be applied for a specific user when the package is deployed to a computer running the App-V 5.1 client.

segment.source: Deployment Configuration File (DeploymentConfig) – Allows you to specify or modify the default settings for a package.
segment.target: Deployment Configuration File (DeploymentConfig) – Allows you to specify or modify the default settings for a package.

segment.source: These settings will be applied for all users when a package is deployed to a computer running the App-V 5.1 client.
segment.target: These settings will be applied for all users when a package is deployed to a computer running the App-V 5.1 client.

segment.source: To customize the settings for a package for a specific set of users on a computer or to make changes that will be applied to local user locations such as HKCU, the UserConfig file should be used.
segment.target: To customize the settings for a package for a specific set of users on a computer or to make changes that will be applied to local user locations such as HKCU, the UserConfig file should be used.

segment.source: To modify the default settings of a package for all users on a machine or to make changes that will be applied to global locations such as HKEYLOCALMACHINE and the all users folder, the DeploymentConfig file should be used.
segment.target: To modify the default settings of a package for all users on a machine or to make changes that will be applied to global locations such as HKEYLOCALMACHINE and the all users folder, the DeploymentConfig file should be used.

segment.source: The UserConfig file provides configuration settings that can be applied to a single user without affecting any other users on a client:
segment.target: The UserConfig file provides configuration settings that can be applied to a single user without affecting any other users on a client:

segment.source: Extensions that will be integrated into the native system per user:- shortcuts, File-Type associations, URL Protocols, AppPaths, Software Clients and COM
segment.target: Extensions that will be integrated into the native system per user:- shortcuts, File-Type associations, URL Protocols, AppPaths, Software Clients and COM

segment.source: Virtual Subsystems:- Application Objects, Environment variables, Registry modifications, Services and Fonts
segment.target: Virtual Subsystems:- Application Objects, Environment variables, Registry modifications, Services and Fonts

segment.source: Managing Authority (for controlling co-existence of package with App-V 4.6)
segment.target: Managing Authority (for controlling co-existence of package with App-V 4.6)

segment.source: The DeploymentConfig file provides configuration settings in two sections, one relative to the machine context and one relative to the user context providing the same capabilities listed in the UserConfig list above:
segment.target: The DeploymentConfig file provides configuration settings in two sections, one relative to the machine context and one relative to the user context providing the same capabilities listed in the UserConfig list above:

segment.source: Extensions that can only be applied globally for all users
segment.target: Extensions that can only be applied globally for all users

segment.source: Virtual Subsystems that can be configured for global machine locations e.g. registry
segment.target: Virtual Subsystems that can be configured for global machine locations e.g. registry

segment.source: The structure of the App-V 5.1 Dynamic Configuration file is explained in the following section.
segment.target: The structure of the App-V 5.1 Dynamic Configuration file is explained in the following section.

segment.source: Header - the header of a dynamic user configuration file is as follows:
segment.target: Header - the header of a dynamic user configuration file is as follows:

segment.source: The PackageId is the same value as exists in the Manifest file.
segment.target: The PackageId is the same value as exists in the Manifest file.

segment.source: Body - the body of the Dynamic User Configuration file can include all the app extension points that are defined in the Manifest file, as well as information to configure virtual applications.
segment.target: Body - the body of the Dynamic User Configuration file can include all the app extension points that are defined in the Manifest file, as well as information to configure virtual applications.

segment.source: There are four subsections allowed in the body:
segment.target: There are four subsections allowed in the body:

segment.source: Applications - All app-extensions that are contained in the Manifest file within a package are assigned with an Application ID, which is also defined in the manifest file.
segment.target: Applications - All app-extensions that are contained in the Manifest file within a package are assigned with an Application ID, which is also defined in the manifest file.

segment.source: This allows you to enable or disable all the extensions for a given application within a package.
segment.target: This allows you to enable or disable all the extensions for a given application within a package.

segment.source: The Application ID must exist in the Manifest file or it will be ignored.
segment.target: The Application ID must exist in the Manifest file or it will be ignored.

segment.source: !-- No new application can be defined in policy.
segment.target: !-- No new application can be defined in policy.

segment.source: AppV Client will ignore any application ID that is not also in the Manifest file --
segment.target: AppV Client will ignore any application ID that is not also in the Manifest file --

segment.source: Subsystems - AppExtensions and other subsystems are arranged as subnodes under the Subsystems:
segment.target: Subsystems - AppExtensions and other subsystems are arranged as subnodes under the Subsystems:

segment.source: Each subsystem can be enabled/disabled using the “Enabled” attribute.
segment.target: Each subsystem can be enabled/disabled using the “Enabled” attribute.

segment.source: Below are the various subsystems and usage samples.
segment.target: Below are the various subsystems and usage samples.

segment.source: Those subsystems are:- shortcuts, File-Type associations, URL Protocols, AppPaths, Software Clients and COM
segment.target: Those subsystems are:- shortcuts, File-Type associations, URL Protocols, AppPaths, Software Clients and COM

segment.source: Extension Subsystems can be enabled and disabled independently of the content.
segment.target: Extension Subsystems can be enabled and disabled independently of the content.

segment.source: Thus if Shortcuts are enabled, The client will use the shortcuts contained within the manifest by default.
segment.target: Thus if Shortcuts are enabled, The client will use the shortcuts contained within the manifest by default.

segment.source: Each Extension Subsystem can contain an Extensions node.
segment.target: Each Extension Subsystem can contain an Extensions node.

segment.source: If this child element is present, the client will ignore the content in the Manifest file for that subsystem and only use the content in the configuration file.
segment.target: If this child element is present, the client will ignore the content in the Manifest file for that subsystem and only use the content in the configuration file.

segment.source: If the user defined this in either the dynamic or deployment config file:
segment.target: If the user defined this in either the dynamic or deployment config file:

segment.source: If the user defined only the following:
segment.target: If the user defined only the following:

segment.source: If the user defines the following
segment.target: If the user defines the following

segment.source: Then all the shortcuts within the manifest will still be ignored.
segment.target: Then all the shortcuts within the manifest will still be ignored.

segment.source: There will be no shortcuts integrated.
segment.target: There will be no shortcuts integrated.

segment.source: Shortcuts: This controls shortcuts that will be integrated into the local system.
segment.target: Shortcuts: This controls shortcuts that will be integrated into the local system.

segment.source: Below is a sample with 2 shortcuts:
segment.target: Below is a sample with 2 shortcuts:

segment.source: File-Type Associations: Associates File-types with programs to open by default as well as setup the context menu.
segment.target: File-Type Associations: Associates File-types with programs to open by default as well as setup the context menu.

segment.source: (MIME types can also be setup using this susbsystem).
segment.target: (MIME types can also be setup using this susbsystem).

segment.source: URL Protocols: This controls the URL Protocols that are integrated into the local registry of the client machine e.g. “mailto:”.
segment.target: URL Protocols: This controls the URL Protocols that are integrated into the local registry of the client machine e.g. “mailto:”.

segment.source: Software Clients: Allows the app to register as an Email client, news reader, media player and makes the app visible in the Set Program Access and Computer Defaults UI.
segment.target: Software Clients: Allows the app to register as an Email client, news reader, media player and makes the app visible in the Set Program Access and Computer Defaults UI.

segment.source: In most cases you should only need to enable and disable it.
segment.target: In most cases you should only need to enable and disable it.

segment.source: There is also a control to enable and disable the email client specifically if you want the other clients still enabled except for that client.
segment.target: There is also a control to enable and disable the email client specifically if you want the other clients still enabled except for that client.

segment.source: AppPaths:- If an application for example contoso.exe is registered with an apppath name of “myapp”, it allows you type “myapp” under the run menu and it will open contoso.exe.
segment.target: AppPaths:- If an application for example contoso.exe is registered with an apppath name of “myapp”, it allows you type “myapp” under the run menu and it will open contoso.exe.

segment.source: COM: Allows an Application register Local COM servers.
segment.target: COM: Allows an Application register Local COM servers.

segment.source: Mode can be Integration, Isolated or Off.
segment.target: Mode can be Integration, Isolated or Off.

segment.source: In addition to Extensions, other subsystems can be enabled/disabled and edited:
segment.target: In addition to Extensions, other subsystems can be enabled/disabled and edited:

segment.source: Virtual Registry: Used if you want to set a registry in the Virtual Registry within HKCU
segment.target: Virtual Registry: Used if you want to set a registry in the Virtual Registry within HKCU

segment.source: UserScripts – Scripts can be used to setup or alter the virtual environment as well as execute scripts at time of deployment or removal, before an application executes, or they can be used to “clean up” the environment after the application terminates.
segment.target: UserScripts – Scripts can be used to setup or alter the virtual environment as well as execute scripts at time of deployment or removal, before an application executes, or they can be used to “clean up” the environment after the application terminates.

segment.source: Please reference a sample User configuration file that is output by the sequencer to see a sample script.
segment.target: Please reference a sample User configuration file that is output by the sequencer to see a sample script.

segment.source: The Scripts section below provides more information on the various triggers that can be used.
segment.target: The Scripts section below provides more information on the various triggers that can be used.

segment.source: ManagingAuthority – Can be used when 2 versions of your package are co-existing on the same machine, one deployed to App-V 4.6 and the other deployed on App-V 5.0.
segment.target: ManagingAuthority – Can be used when 2 versions of your package are co-existing on the same machine, one deployed to App-V 4.6 and the other deployed on App-V 5.0.

segment.source: To Allow App-V vNext to take over App-V 4.6 extension points for the named package enter the following in the UserConfig file (where PackageName is the Package GUID in App-V 4.6:
segment.target: To Allow App-V vNext to take over App-V 4.6 extension points for the named package enter the following in the UserConfig file (where PackageName is the Package GUID in App-V 4.6:

segment.source: Header - The header of a Deployment Configuration file is as follows:
segment.target: Header - The header of a Deployment Configuration file is as follows:

segment.source: The PackageId is the same value as exists in the manifest file.
segment.target: The PackageId is the same value as exists in the manifest file.

segment.source: Body - The body of the deployment configuration file includes two sections:
segment.target: Body - The body of the deployment configuration file includes two sections:

segment.source: User Configuration section –allows the same content as the User Configuration file described in the previous section.
segment.target: User Configuration section –allows the same content as the User Configuration file described in the previous section.

segment.source: When the package is published to a user, any appextensions configuration settings in this section will override corresponding settings in the Manifest within the package unless a user configuration file is also provided.
segment.target: When the package is published to a user, any appextensions configuration settings in this section will override corresponding settings in the Manifest within the package unless a user configuration file is also provided.

segment.source: If a UserConfig file is also provided, it will be used instead of the User settings in the deployment configuration file.
segment.target: If a UserConfig file is also provided, it will be used instead of the User settings in the deployment configuration file.

segment.source: If the package is published globally, then only the contents of the deployment configuration file will be used in combination with the manifest.
segment.target: If the package is published globally, then only the contents of the deployment configuration file will be used in combination with the manifest.

segment.source: Machine Configuration section–contains information that can be configured only for an entire machine, not for a specific user on the machine.
segment.target: Machine Configuration section–contains information that can be configured only for an entire machine, not for a specific user on the machine.

segment.source: For example, HKEYLOCALMACHINE registry keys in the VFS.
segment.target: For example, HKEYLOCALMACHINE registry keys in the VFS.

segment.source: User Configuration - use the previous Dynamic User Configuration file section for information on settings that are provided in the user configuration section of the Deployment Configuration file.
segment.target: User Configuration - use the previous Dynamic User Configuration file section for information on settings that are provided in the user configuration section of the Deployment Configuration file.

segment.source: Machine Configuration - the Machine configuration section of the Deployment Configuration File is used to configure information that can be set only for an entire machine, not for a specific user on the computer.
segment.target: Machine Configuration - the Machine configuration section of the Deployment Configuration File is used to configure information that can be set only for an entire machine, not for a specific user on the computer.

segment.source: For example, HKEYLOCALMACHINE registry keys in the Virtual Registry.
segment.target: For example, HKEYLOCALMACHINE registry keys in the Virtual Registry.

segment.source: There are four subsections allowed in under this element
segment.target: There are four subsections allowed in under this element

segment.source: Subsystems - AppExtensions and other subsystems are arranged as subnodes under Subsystems:
segment.target: Subsystems - AppExtensions and other subsystems are arranged as subnodes under Subsystems:

segment.source: The following section displays the various subsystems and usage samples.
segment.target: The following section displays the various subsystems and usage samples.

segment.source: Some subsystems (Extension Subsystems) control Extensions which can only apply to all users.
segment.target: Some subsystems (Extension Subsystems) control Extensions which can only apply to all users.

segment.source: Because this can only apply to all users, the package must be published globally in order for this type of extension to be integrated into the local system.
segment.target: Because this can only apply to all users, the package must be published globally in order for this type of extension to be integrated into the local system.

segment.source: The same rules for controls and settings that apply to the Extensions in the User Configuration also apply to those in the MachineConfiguration section.
segment.target: The same rules for controls and settings that apply to the Extensions in the User Configuration also apply to those in the MachineConfiguration section.

segment.source: Application Capabilities: Used by default programs in windows operating system Interface.
segment.target: Application Capabilities: Used by default programs in windows operating system Interface.

segment.source: Allows an application to register itself as capable of opening certain file extensions, as a contender for the start menu internet browser slot, as capable of opening certain windows MIME types.
segment.target: Allows an application to register itself as capable of opening certain file extensions, as a contender for the start menu internet browser slot, as capable of opening certain windows MIME types.

segment.source: This extension also makes the virtual application visible in the Set Default Programs UI.:
segment.target: This extension also makes the virtual application visible in the Set Default Programs UI.:

segment.source: In addition to Extensions, other subsystems can be edited:
segment.target: In addition to Extensions, other subsystems can be edited:

segment.source: Machine Wide Virtual Registry: Used when you want to set a registry key in the virtual registry within HKEYLocalMachine
segment.target: Machine Wide Virtual Registry: Used when you want to set a registry key in the virtual registry within HKEYLocalMachine

segment.source: ProductSourceURLOptOut: Indicates whether the URL for the package can be modified globally through PackageSourceRoot (to support branch office scenarios).
segment.target: ProductSourceURLOptOut: Indicates whether the URL for the package can be modified globally through PackageSourceRoot (to support branch office scenarios).

segment.source: Default is false and the setting change takes effect on the next launch.
segment.target: Default is false and the setting change takes effect on the next launch.

segment.source: MachineScripts – Package can be configured to execute scripts at time of deployment, publishing or removal.
segment.target: MachineScripts – Package can be configured to execute scripts at time of deployment, publishing or removal.

segment.source: Please reference a sample deployment configuration file that is generated by the sequencer to see a sample script.
segment.target: Please reference a sample deployment configuration file that is generated by the sequencer to see a sample script.

segment.source: The Scripts section below provides more information on the various triggers that can be used
segment.target: The Scripts section below provides more information on the various triggers that can be used

segment.source: TerminateChildProcess:- An application executable can be specified, whose child processes will be terminated when the application exe process is terminated.
segment.target: TerminateChildProcess:- An application executable can be specified, whose child processes will be terminated when the application exe process is terminated.

segment.source: The following table describes the various script events and the context under which they can be run.
segment.target: The following table describes the various script events and the context under which they can be run.

segment.source: Can be specified in Deployment Configuration
segment.target: Can be specified in Deployment Configuration

segment.source: Can be specified in User Configuration
segment.target: Can be specified in User Configuration

segment.source: Can run in the Virtual Environment of the package
segment.target: Can run in the Virtual Environment of the package

segment.source: Can be run in the context of a specific application
segment.target: Can be run in the context of a specific application

segment.source: Runs in system/user context: (Deployment Configuration, User Configuration)
segment.target: Runs in system/user context: (Deployment Configuration, User Configuration)

segment.source: Using multiple scripts on a single event trigger
segment.target: Using multiple scripts on a single event trigger

segment.source: App-V 5.1 supports the use of multiple scripts on a single event trigger for App-V packages, including packages that you convert from App-V 4.6 to App-V 5.0 or later.
segment.target: App-V 5.1 supports the use of multiple scripts on a single event trigger for App-V packages, including packages that you convert from App-V 4.6 to App-V 5.0 or later.

segment.source: To enable the use of multiple scripts, App-V 5.1 uses a script launcher application, named ScriptRunner.exe, which is installed as part of the App-V client installation.
segment.target: To enable the use of multiple scripts, App-V 5.1 uses a script launcher application, named ScriptRunner.exe, which is installed as part of the App-V client installation.

segment.source: How to use multiple scripts on a single event trigger:
segment.target: How to use multiple scripts on a single event trigger:

segment.source: For each script that you want to run, pass that script as an argument to the ScriptRunner.exe application.
segment.target: For each script that you want to run, pass that script as an argument to the ScriptRunner.exe application.

segment.source: The application then runs each script separately, along with the arguments that you specify for each script.
segment.target: The application then runs each script separately, along with the arguments that you specify for each script.

segment.source: Use only one script (ScriptRunner.exe) per trigger.
segment.target: Use only one script (ScriptRunner.exe) per trigger.

segment.source: We recommended that you run the multi-script line from a command prompt first to make sure that all arguments are built correctly before adding them to the deployment configuration file.
segment.target: We recommended that you run the multi-script line from a command prompt first to make sure that all arguments are built correctly before adding them to the deployment configuration file.

segment.source: Using the following example file and table, modify the deployment or user configuration file to add the scripts that you want to run.
segment.target: Using the following example file and table, modify the deployment or user configuration file to add the scripts that you want to run.

segment.source: Name of the event trigger for which you are running a script, such as adding a package or publishing a package.
segment.target: Name of the event trigger for which you are running a script, such as adding a package or publishing a package.

segment.source: The script launcher application that is installed as part of the App-V client installation.
segment.target: The script launcher application that is installed as part of the App-V client installation.

segment.source: Although ScriptRunner.exe is installed as part of the App-V client, the location of the App-V client must be in %path% or ScriptRunner will not run.
segment.target: Although ScriptRunner.exe is installed as part of the App-V client, the location of the App-V client must be in %path% or ScriptRunner will not run.

segment.source: ScriptRunner.exe is typically located in the C:\Program Files\Microsoft Application Virtualization\Client folder.
segment.target: ScriptRunner.exe is typically located in the C:\Program Files\Microsoft Application Virtualization\Client folder.

segment.source: Token that represents the actual script that you want to run.
segment.target: Token that represents the actual script that you want to run.

segment.source: – Name of the script that you want to run.
segment.target: – Name of the script that you want to run.

segment.source: – Arguments for the script that you want to run.
segment.target: – Arguments for the script that you want to run.

segment.source: – Token that represents the execution options for
segment.target: – Token that represents the execution options for

segment.source: – Token that informs ScriptRunner to wait for execution of to complete before proceeding to the next script.
segment.target: – Token that informs ScriptRunner to wait for execution of to complete before proceeding to the next script.

segment.source: – Token that informs ScriptRunner to stop running the current script after number of seconds.
segment.target: – Token that informs ScriptRunner to stop running the current script after number of seconds.

segment.source: All other specified scripts will still run.
segment.target: All other specified scripts will still run.

segment.source: – Token that informs ScriptRunner to stop running all scripts that haven't yet run and to roll back an error to the App-V client.
segment.target: – Token that informs ScriptRunner to stop running all scripts that haven't yet run and to roll back an error to the App-V client.

segment.source: Waits for overall completion of ScriptRunner.exe.
segment.target: Waits for overall completion of ScriptRunner.exe.

segment.source: Set the timeout value for the overall runner to be greater than or equal to the sum of the timeout values on the individual scripts.
segment.target: Set the timeout value for the overall runner to be greater than or equal to the sum of the timeout values on the individual scripts.

segment.source: If any individual script reported an error and rollbackonerror was set to , then ScriptRunner would report the error to App-V client.
segment.target: If any individual script reported an error and rollbackonerror was set to , then ScriptRunner would report the error to App-V client.

segment.source: ScriptRunner will run any script whose file type is associated with an application installed on the computer.
segment.target: ScriptRunner will run any script whose file type is associated with an application installed on the computer.

segment.source: If the associated application is missing, or the script’s file type is not associated with any application on the computer, the script will not run.
segment.target: If the associated application is missing, or the script’s file type is not associated with any application on the computer, the script will not run.

segment.source: Create a Dynamic Configuration file using an App-V 5.1 Manifest file
segment.target: Create a Dynamic Configuration file using an App-V 5.1 Manifest file

segment.source: You can create the Dynamic Configuration file using one of three methods: either manually, using the App-V 5.1 Management Console or sequencing a package, which will be generated with 2 sample files.
segment.target: You can create the Dynamic Configuration file using one of three methods: either manually, using the App-V 5.1 Management Console or sequencing a package, which will be generated with 2 sample files.

segment.source: For more information about how to create the file using the App-V 5.1 Management Console see, How to Create a Custom Configuration File by Using the App-V 5.1 Management Console.
segment.target: For more information about how to create the file using the App-V 5.1 Management Console see, How to Create a Custom Configuration File by Using the App-V 5.1 Management Console.

segment.source: To create the file manually, the information above in previous sections can be combined into a single file.
segment.target: To create the file manually, the information above in previous sections can be combined into a single file.

segment.source: We recommend you use files generated by the sequencer.
segment.target: We recommend you use files generated by the sequencer.

segment.source: Add or vote on suggestions here.
segment.target: Add or vote on suggestions here.

segment.source: For App-V issues, use the App-V TechNet Forum.
segment.target: For App-V issues, use the App-V TechNet Forum.

segment.target: How to Apply the Deployment Configuration File by Using PowerShell
